title: 106_s2902
content: The Act titled "Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000" amends the Communications Act of 1934 to regulate the provision of advanced services by incumbent local exchange carriers. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 amends the Communications Act of 1934 to exempt incumbent local exchange carriers from certain requirements related to interconnection, network elements, advanced services, and premises or structures used for specific network elements. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from certain requirements related to interconnection, network elements, and premises used for specific network elements. This includes optical fiber in the incumbent's distribution network used exclusively for telecommunications service to residential subscribers, deployed in specific scenarios and capable of providing telephone exchange service, data, and video. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from certain requirements related to interconnection, network elements, and premises used for specific network elements. This includes providing advanced services to a percentage of customers within a state within a specified timeframe. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from certain requirements related to providing advanced services to all customers within a state within a specified timeframe. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from certain requirements related to providing advanced services at a rated speed of 128 kilobits per second or more. If carriers fail to comply, regulatory relief will not apply to them. Pricing flexibility is granted for advanced services, exempting them from common carrier regulation in certain exchanges. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from certain requirements for providing advanced services. Carriers can seek pricing flexibility by filing a petition with the Commission. If advanced services are offered by an unaffiliated provider, the petition is approved unconditionally. Rates, terms, and conditions of advanced services outside an incumbent's territory are also addressed. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from regulation for advanced services outside their territory if they were not the incumbent carrier on February 8, 1996. The carrier must file a schedule of charges with the Commission for any advanced service not deemed competitive, which becomes effective 2 days after filing unless the Commission objects. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from regulation for advanced services outside their territory. If a State determines that a carrier has failed to comply with collocation or loop provisioning rules, the carrier will no longer be subject to certain regulations unless reinstated. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from regulation for advanced services outside their territory. If a State determines that a carrier has failed to comply with collocation or loop provisioning rules, the carrier can petition for reinstatement of regulations. The burden of proof is on the complainant for reinstatement. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from regulation for advanced services outside their territory. If a State fails to make a determination on a petition within 90 days, the carrier is deemed in compliance with collocation and loop provisioning rules. Incumbent carriers using remote terminals for advanced services must provide access to requesting telecommunications carriers. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from regulation for advanced services outside their territory. Incumbent carriers using remote terminals for advanced services must provide access to requesting telecommunications carriers for subloop elements and rights of way. Collocation at a remote terminal is not required by law. Definitions include 'incumbent local exchange carrier,' 'customer premises,' and 'remote terminal.' The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 exempts incumbent local exchange carriers from regulation for advanced services outside their territory. Remote terminals are defined as the point in the carrier's network where advanced services are deployed and subloop unbundling is provided. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 amends Section 251(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, stating that local exchange carriers are not required to make payments for telecommunications connecting to the Internet or Internet service providers. This communication is deemed interstate and falls under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Commission, without altering existing interconnection agreements. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 amends Section 251(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, stating that local exchange carriers are not required to provide network elements on an unbundled basis unless predominantly used for telephone exchange service. The Broadband Internet Regulatory Relief Act of 2000 amends Section 251(f) of the Communications Act of 1934 to exempt local exchange carriers with fewer than 2 percent of the nation's subscriber lines from common carrier regulations for advanced services. These carriers can choose to continue filing tariffs for advanced services and participate in National Exchange Carrier Association pooling arrangements. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In General, Section 3 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include definitions for "advanced service" and "advanced service provider" related to high-speed internet capabilities. The term 'advanced service provider' is defined as any provider of advanced services. Section 271(c)(1)(A) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to reflect this definition.
